utterances: Like other advertisers, Goldstein sees the potential.
One of his company's clients, Dove, created its own online promotion when it introduced a new bath product.
The spots featured actress Felicity Huffman.
(Soundbite of Dove commercial)
(As Character) Oh!
There's nothing like a nice relaxing shower at night to clear all the cobwebs out of your mind and help you sleep.
The spots got four million hits.
That's good, Goldstein says, but advertisers still aren't sure what works in the digital realm.
Nor have they figured out how much to pay for their Web experiments.
Whatever happens, Goldstein thinks the Internet won't eclipse broadcast television anytime soon.
That's because television remains by far the biggest guaranteed aggregator of eyeballs.

And while lots of players, from companies like Amazon.com to high school kids in a garage, are trying to come up with a big Internet hit, CBS's Kramer says the networks are the only ones positioned to play the game consistently.
So, Kramer figures, the networks will continue to dominate, and he thinks their Web sites will dominate too.
You know, people do quickly get into a habit of going to a few Web sites.
And I think TV is probably the same.
Seven hundred channels on your Direct TV and you still wind up going to the same half a dozen.

Maybe the networks can't own every hit on the Web, but when someone rises from obscurity by posting clever videos on a site like YouTube, CBS or some other network is likely to be there with a check in hand.
Kim Masters, NPR News, Los Angeles.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Melissa Block.
And I'm Michele Norris.
Next week, Israel will begin its withdrawal from the Gaza Strip.
Eight thousand Jewish settlers are being ordered to leave their communities; their homes will be torn down.
The Israeli army will leave Gaza, as well, and the territory will be left to the Palestinians.
Never before has Israel carried out such a significant withdrawal from territory some claim is Israel's biblical heritage.
It has provoked deep divisions within Israel, and on the Palestinian side, quite a bit of confusion.
NPR's Mike Shuster reports.
(Soundbite of crowd noise)
Settlers assemble nervously in Kfar Darom.

This was the first Jewish settlement established in Gaza three years after Israel seized the territory in the 1967 Six Day War, and it will be one of the first Jewish settlements in Gaza to be dismantled beginning next week.
Israel has always been a contentious and raucous society, but the Gaza pullout has deepened its divisions perhaps like nothing else in decades.

In practical terms, it pits the Israeli army, long the symbol of Israel's pride and power, against a determined minority with the profound belief that it is politically suicidal and against God's will to give up one inch of land, no matter what the circumstances.
Tovah Haddad(ph), a settler in Kfar Darom, is preparing for the day next week when the soldiers will come to her door.
She likens the conflict to a war.
It's different from all the wars that we were--very strong wars that we were in against the enemies.
Here, it's our brothers coming to us.
But we'll accept them as brothers, and we hope that they'll just look at us and look in our eyes and turn back and go outside and tell the government, `We can't do our--what you told us to do.'
There are only some 8,000 Jewish settlers in Gaza, a thin strip of desert just north of Egypt's Sinai Peninsula along the Mediterranean.
They live in 21 settlements surrounded by a million and a half Palestinians.
The Israeli army keeps the two communities apart.
More than a thousand supporters have infiltrated the settlements in recent weeks to bolster the ranks of those who will resist the pullout.
Thousands more have protested in rallies and marches.
Rahel Golan(ph), a high school teacher from Jerusalem, brought her 10 children to Kfar Darom a month ago to stand with the settlers.
It's a national calamity what's happening now.
If we give away this land to murderers, then we're bringing the terror that we've seen here in the past closer and closer to the homes of all the Jews in Israel.
The Gaza withdrawal is the policy of Israel's controversial right-wing prime minister, Ariel Sharon.
For most of his career in the army and government, Sharon has sided fiercely with the settler movement.
Now he has come to believe that Israel's security will be better served by the removal of the settlers from Gaza and from four isolated settlements in the northern West Bank.
This has split the right wing like never before.
Just a few days ago, former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu resigned from the government, signaling his intention to run against Sharon for the leadership of the Likud Party.
Uzi Landau, a longtime ally of Sharon, is now also challenging him.
Speaking to the Kfar Darom settlers, Landau called the removal of Jews from Gaza ethnic cleansing.
It is tearing apart our society.
It is boosting tremendously terrorism.
The terrorist organizations in Iraq and in Afghanistan see how democracy is knuckling under.
Verdi accuses the ultra-Orthodox of behaving as though they were outside the laws of the state.
He asks whether they are trying to start a war among brothers.
Oppenheimer quickly retorts that they are not brothers.
For NPR News, I'm Sheera Frenkel.
